pages.title: Information
pages.tabDetailText1:
Palacio de la Aljafería's opening times

Mornings

(except Thursdays and Fridays*)

Throughout the year

From 10am to 2pm

Guided Tours:

10.30pm, 11.30am, 12.30am.

Afternoons

(except Thursdays*)

From November to March

From 4pm to 6.30pm

Sunday afternoons closed

Guided Tours: 4.30pm, 5.30pm

From April to October

From 4.30pm to 8pm

Guided Tours:

4.30pm, 5.30pm, 6.30pm

*Due to the activity of The Parliament of Aragon, on Thursdays (all day) and Fridays (mornings) the Palace cannot be visited except by pre-arranged groups.

In January, July and August the Palace can be visited every day of the week, at the above times.

Access to the Palace ends 30 minutes before closing time.

GROUPS:

Organised group visits from Monday to Saturday.

Fax. 976 28 96 86

pages.subtitle: Taifal Palace
pages.title: Taifal Palace
pages.description:
Taifal Palace

The construction of this palace dates back to the second half of the 11th century, during the reign of the Taifa monarch of Zaragoza, Abu Yafar al Muqtadir Billah.
pages.scrollText1: Detalle de los techos de la Aljafería.

pages.subtitle: Mediaeval Palace
pages.title: Mediaeval Palace
pages.description:
Mediaeval Palace

In 1118, Alfonso I El Batallador (The Warrior) won back the city of Zaragoza. It was then, when the Aljaferia became a Christian fortified palace.
pages.scrollText1: Detalle de los techos de la Aljafería.

pages.subtitle: Catholic Monarchs' Palace
pages.title: Catholic Monarchs' Palace
pages.description:
Catholic Monarchs' Palace

Ordered to be built by the Catholic Monarchs during the last lustrums of the 15th century - between 1488 and 1496 - over the northern wing of the Islamic enclosure.

pages.subtitle: The Aljaferia Palace
pages.title: The Aljaferia Palace
pages.description:
To speak of the Zaragoza Aljaferia means speaking about one of the most outstanding architectonic heritage ensembles of Aragon, an ensemble which, due to its magnitude and importance, symbolises the historic and artistic journey of Aragon.
When visitors enter the building, they see the Islamic palace, of exquisite beauty, the Christian evolution with its reforms and extensions, the palace of the Catholic Monarchs or, taking a giant leap forward in time, the interventions that have made it possible for the palace to house the Parliament of Aragon today.
The Aljaferia is the result of a long restoration process that has ended with the building as it is today, where it is possible to distinguish and differentiate the original remains from the reconstructed part of the building. In 2001, the UNESCO included Aragon Mudejar in the World Heritage list, highlighting that the Aljaferia palace is one of the most representative and iconic monuments of Aragonese Mudejar art.
pages.nextSpaceText: Enter through the main door, flanked by the two crenellated towers.

pages.subtitle: St. Martin’s Courtyard
pages.title: St. Martin’s Courtyard
pages.description:
After passing through the walled enclosure, we enter St. Martin’s courtyard, which takes its name from the chapel situated on the right of the entrance arch.

The amalgam of existing buildings and styles in the Aljaferia palace can best be contemplated from this courtyard. Archaeological remains found on site can be seen, as well as evidence of a bent entrance door from the original Muslim palace, the latticework of the oratory, St. Martin’s chapel, in Mudejar style, the windows of the halls of lost steps of the Catholic Monarchs’ palace and also the main façade of the new building that is now the seat of the Parliament of Aragon.

St. Martin’s chapel forms part of the reforms carried out by the Christian monarchs on the Aljaferia between the 12th and 15th centuries. Noteworthy, on the outside, is the Mudejar exposed brick doorway. This doorway has a moulded entrance arch, which is housed within another larger one with pointed arch. The decoration of the arch combines three basic elements: mixtilinear arches in the tympanum, medallions in the spandrels and a diamond-patterned panel as an alfiz.
pages.scrollText1: Restos del primitivo Patio de San Martín.
pages.scrollText2: Detalle del lado del patio donde se situa el edificio que alberga las Cortes de Aragón.
pages.scrollText3: Detalle del lado del patio donde se encuentra la Iglesia de San Martín.
pages.nextSpaceText: Enter the next courtyard, one of the most remarkable artistic areas of the building.

pages.subtitle: St. Isabella’s Courtyard
pages.title: St. Isabella’s Courtyard
pages.description:
This is the element that unifies the entire Muslim courtyard as both the rooms and the porticoes in the northern and southern wings look onto it. This is a courtyard-garden conceived as a private space, hidden from view from the outside. When we see the water, the vegetation and the decorative elements, we can easily imagine ourselves in the times of splendour of the Aljaferia, and the verses composed by Abu Yafar al Muqtadir Billah, the poet king of the Zaragoza Taifa take on a meaning:

Oh palace of joy! ¡Oh, golden hall!

Thanks to you I reached the height of my yearning.

And, although my kingdom were to have nothing else,

for me you are everything that I could long for.
pages.scrollText1: Aquí podemos apreciar la perfecta inclusión de la vegetación en este espacio arquitectónico.
pages.scrollText2: Estos arcos han sido remodelados conforme al estilo y �poca del patio, aunque no sabemos con certeza si éste fué su aspecto original.
pages.scrollText3: Detalle de la alberca del lado sur, recuperada totalmente gracias a su buen estado de conservación.
pages.nextSpaceText: The northern portico of the Islamic palace is located next to St. Isabella’s courtyard.

pages.subtitle: Halls on the Northern side of the Taifa palace
pages.title: Halls on the Northern side of the Taifa palace
pages.description:
The rooms that we are in now respond to a very simple tripartite structure: the throne room or "marble room" and two side rooms that were possibly private bedchambers, of which only the one on the western side has been preserved. The walls would originally have been coated with ataurique (stylised plant motifs): there were also alabaster plinths and sumptuous slabs of white marble. Today, only a few fragments of the original declaration remain but these, together with fragments preserved in museums, have permitted the partial re-composition of the original decoration that existed in this space. The "marble room" is connected at the ends to the northern portico with two pointed horseshoe arches that are cladded on multilobed arches and, in the centre there is a curious combination of interlaced mixtilinear arches, which are superimposed, at height, by other simpler horseshoe arches.

The actual portico extends in front of the rooms of the residential palace, with large multilobed archways that reach the courtyard. This architectonic system was very much to the liking of the Muslim mindset, which is based on the idea of creating separate spaces by means of a series of archways that are harmoniously multiplied and that act as visual screens.
pages.scrollText2: Detalle decorativo en el que podemos observar el abarrocamiento y complejidad del conjunto.
pages.scrollText3: Detalle de la ornamentación en los capiteles.
pages.nextSpaceText: When you enter this area, you will find the oratory on the right-hand side (eastern side of the northern portico).

pages.subtitle: Oratory
pages.title: Oratory
pages.description: This is located on the eastern side of the northern portico and is accessed through a horseshoe arched doorway, with S-shaped arch stones and with an alfiz or arrabá (space between arch and alfiz) over which there is a frieze of interlaced semicircular arches. The doorway is completed with copious decoration in plaster, based on atauriques and cufic inscriptions. On the interior, we find a very small and private space. It only has one floor which, at height, becomes octagonal in shape through arches in the corners. The prayer niche or mihrab faces south-east, which was normal in mosques of the Iberian Peninsula. Higher up, the first floor has a splendid structure of mixtilinear arches, as well as fine and profuse ataurique decoration. This floor is separated from the second by a frieze which bears a cufic inscription taken from Sura 6 of the Koran. Above the frieze there is a gallery of small lobed arches where remains of the pictorial decoration of Moslem times are still visible. The original dome disappeared when the Catholic Monarchs ordered their fortified palace to be built: the current one repeats the model of those that exist in the maqsurah of the Cordoba mosque.
pages.scrollText1: Puerta de entrada al nicho del Mihrab con arco de herradura,orientada hacia La Meca.
pages.scrollText2: Detalle de la puerta de entrada desde la que se aprecia el carácter oscuro e intimista de este espacio.
pages.scrollText3: Esta cúpula se ha construido de forma que sea fácilmente sustituible en caso de que se llegasen a encontrar datos de su aspecto original.
pages.nextSpaceText: From St. Isabella’s courtyard, continue towards the third courtyard.  Before you reach it, turn right, passing through a room where different pieces are displayed (latticework, capitals,… ).  You will reach the next room, which is on the right.

pages.subtitle: Lower room of the Mudejar Palace
pages.title: Lower room of the Mudejar Palace
pages.description:
The so-called “lower room” or reception room forms part of the reforms and extensions made to the Aljaferia on the orders of the Monarchs of Aragon in Christian mediaeval times. Although these interventions did not form an architectonic unit, because they were carried out throughout the length and breadth of the Islamic palace, as a whole they are considered as one of the main focal points of Aragon Mudejar art.

This space has sometimes been called “room of the aljibe” as the Moslem well or aljibe is located under its floor. It is accessed from the ground floor of the Troubadour tower along a corridor with vaulted ceiling. This well is very large, as the diameter of the wellhead is about five metres and it is some twelve metres deep; in fact it cuts through the water table of the Ebro River.

What is most surprising about this room is the magnificent heraldic decorative repertoire of its alfarje (flat carved and decorated wooden roof with visible beams), which was recuperated after removing layers and layers of grey paint that it was hidden behind. This alfarje is a document of considerable interest to help understand this phase of the monument.
pages.nextSpaceText: To access the upper rooms of the Mudejar palace, when you leave the ground floor room you will find a staircase opposite it, which will take you to the top floor.

pages.subtitle: Upper rooms of the Mudejar Palace
pages.title: Upper rooms of the Mudejar Palace
pages.description:
The other two rooms that have been preserved of the Christian mediaeval palace are situated on the upper floor and are also covered with magnificent alfarjes, but the decoration that can be seen, based on mythological motifs and shields, is later, as they were repainted in the times of the Catholic Monarchs. There are a few remains from another previous era, consisting in gules bars on gold, which identify these rooms as the ones the chroniclers referred to when they described the sky of bars under which visitors stood.

One of these rooms was connected in Christian times to the third floor of the Troubadour tower, and the other, to St. Isabella’s bed chamber, located in the constructive block situated over the mosque.
pages.nextSpaceText: To access the third floor of the Troubadour Tower, cross the room that contains a large rectangular table.

pages.subtitle: Troubadour Tower
pages.title: Troubadour Tower
pages.description:
This Homage tower is the oldest architectonic part of the Islamic constructions preserved in the Aljfareria, as the lower part, connected to the aljibe that is located under the floor of the lower room of the Christian mediaeval palace, can be dated back to the 10th century. When the Islamic palace of the Aljaferia was built under the dynasty of the Banu Hud, during the second half of the 11th century, the tower was integrated into the northern wall of the outer fortified enclosure.

The tower, seen from the outside, appears as an enormous, solid prism, which has some very small openings that can hardly be seen, finished off with turrets. On the inside, it has five storeys, and according to some authors, the first three were made by the Moslems and the last two were built in Christian times.

The third floor of the tower is connected to the upper rooms of the Christian mediaeval palace. Over the horseshoe arches, there is an inscription in cufic letters which repeats “The Empire belongs to Allah”, and also a series of Mudejar geometric motifs where the names of Aeneas, Love and Venus can be read, which would date back to the 14th century.

A lot of graffiti can be seen on this floor, with symbols, drawings and inscriptions, attributed to prisoners who were kept in the tower, from those sentenced by the Court of the Holy Inquisition, which was set up in the Aljaferia in 1486, to prisoners from other wars that took place in Modern and Contemporary times.

The name of this tower is based on a play from Romantic literature written by Antonio García Gutiérrez. Its argument was used as a source of inspiration for Giuseppe Verdi’s operetta, Il Trovatore.
pages.nextSpaceText: Leave this room and turn to the left, where you will see some models of the building.  Then continue towards the palace of the Catholic Monarchs.

pages.subtitle: Throne Room of the palace of the Catholic Monarchs
pages.title: Throne Room of the palace of the Catholic Monarchs
pages.description:
This room is a singular space due to its size. It measures twenty metres long by almost eight metres wide. There is no decoration on its walls, except for the openings that illuminate the room.

The most noteworthy aspect of this room is the beautiful coffered ceiling: a ceiling made of carved, gilt and polychrome wood, which is supported by thick beams and cross members that are decorated with tracery work and eight-pointed stars, which generate a total of thirty square waffles. On the interior of these waffles there are some octagons with a rosette in the centre with curly leaves and large hanging pine cones, which have traditionally been a symbol related to fertility and immortality. This is all combined with the repeated emblems of the yoke and arrows.

Under the coffered roof there is a gallery of ogee arches, from which the guests could attend and contemplate the majestic sessions on the lower floor (it was probably reserved for ladies, which is why it has this character of matronium that has always been conferred upon it). Between two large mouldings carved with plant and animal motifs, a Latin inscription written in Gothic characters goes round the perimeter of the room, which expresses the symbolic meaning of the palace of the Catholic Monarch.

This inscription, written in Spanish, says the following:

“Ferdinand, King of the Spains, Sicily, Sardinia, Corsica and Balearic Islands, the best of princes, cautious, brave, devout, constant, fair, happy, and Isabella, queen, above all a women known for her devoutness and greatness of spirit, famous victorious spouses with the help of Christ, after freeing Andalusia from the moors, expelling the old and fierce enemy, took great care in building this work, in the year of Salvation of 1492.”
pages.nextSpaceText: Walk around the entire room until you come to a small door on the opposite wall, which will take you to the first Hall of the Lost Steps.

pages.subtitle: Halls of the Lost Steps
pages.title: Halls of the Lost Steps
pages.description:
They are given this name because originally they were used as waiting areas for people who were going to be granted audience in the Throne Room. These halls, which have a square ground plan, are extremely attractive and artistically relevant. This is basically due to two reasons: the first, due to their interesting flooring, made of tiles manufactured in the historical potteries of Muel, and the second, due to its magnificent ceilings: taujeles (flat ceiling covered by wooden framework), made by master Mudejar carpenters, which present a geometrical grid of carved wood, painted and gilded in gold leaf. In the moulded spaces there are abundant motifs of the bundle of arrows and yoke with the Gordian knot, together with the inseparable motto of “Tanto Monta” (They amount to the same), as well as a large number of leafy rosettes, finished with the typical hanging pine cones.

The halls are connected and the lighting is provided by the large windows that open up onto St. Martin’s Courtyard. Of the three halls that originally existed, only two are visible today, as the third was closed by the architect, Francisco Iñiguez when he replaced the dome of the oratory or mosque of the Taifal place. Its ceiling, a gilded and polychrome wooden taujel was taken to a room that is located next to the Throne Room.
pages.nextSpaceText: From the second Hall of the Lost Steps, carry straight on and you will reach the upper corridor or gallery.

pages.subtitle: Gallery or upper corridor and noble staircase
pages.title: Gallery or upper corridor and noble staircase
pages.description: Today, we leave the halls of lost steps by crossing the enclosed gallery that looks onto the courtyard of St. Isabella. This is supported by graceful pillar with torso shafts. It is a space-path that is covered with some small block vaults, where the footprint of its original pictorial decoration can still be seen. The entrance doorway to the Throne Room is quite spectacular. It is divided into three parts, with a three-lobed arch in the centre, over which the official shield of the monarchs is located, sustained by two lions and on the inside, the coats of arms of the kingdoms of Castile, Leon, Aragon, Sicilia and the annexed Granada. The path ends when we go down the noble staircase, with its beautiful plasterwork and spectacular ceiling, based, too, on small block vaults. These contain an interesting pictorial decoration with tempera, with the Catholic Monarchs’ motifs of the yoke and arrows, and an early decoration in grisaille with Renaissance themes.
pages.scrollText3: Para apoyar este mirador, al igual que el resto de las dependencias,fu� necesario seccionar las zonas altas de los salones taifales del s.XI
pages.nextSpaceText: Go down the staircase to go back to St. Isabella’s courtyard.

pages.subtitle: The Parliament of Aragon and the Aljafería
pages.title: The Parliament of Aragon and the Aljafería
pages.description:
Since 1987, inside its old walls, the Aljaferia palace houses the institution that represents all the Aragonese people: the Parliament of Aragon.

From an architectonic viewpoint, and among the interventions carried out by the architects, Mariano Pemán and Luis Franco in the 20th century, we must pay attention to the building constructed to house the new parliamentary hemicycle, situated opposite St. Martin’s chapel. The authors of the project wanted the construction to be isolated from the walls and Taifal palace of the 11th century, ruling out the inclusion of symbolic, emblematic or historicist elements. In fact, its main façade is extremely simple.

The Aljaferia palace, headquarters of the Parliament of Aragon, is visited every year by thousands of people. It has become a place for meeting and dialogue, true evidence of history and a cultural heritage.
pages.nextSpaceText: The Parliament of Aragon and the Aljafería
